Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Ultrahigh efficiency tunable biowaste derived nanofiltration platform for industrial application
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project focuses on the growing and shifting needs of the global filtration market. Contemporary pollution and manufacturing output has resulted in a categorical expansion of filtration needs and new applications. Traditional and modern day air filtration relies heavily on HEPA/ULPA filters, a particular type of high purity fiberglass extruded filter system, which dominates despite the bulk and cost to both the environment and the consumers. HEPA filters make up the majority of filters, and petroleum based, non-biodegradable and multiple filter systems are often needed and employed in series (with for example, carbon filters and UV lamps) to adequately provide the desired filtration results. In comparison, this project focuses on nanofilteration methods and materials which achieves much higher efficacy at a fraction of the energy production cost and is a holistic system of composites that utilizes charged attraction to overcome traditional efficacy barriers. Applicable industries include Biomedical, Semiconductor, Manufacturing, Automotive, etc.

This I-Corps project centers around a novel biodegradable nanotech air filtration platform that includes a nano-mesh of biomimetic functionalized nanofibers to eliminate harmful air pollutants. This project utilizes biodegradable polymeric nanofibers (i.e. chitosan, cellulose) that are naturally derived and modified to target specific pollutants in the air. By using these abundant raw natural polysaccharides, the resulting filtration platform is biocompatible, biodegradable, low cost, and nontoxic. This project includes operation methods and formulations, ideal composite synthesis methods to achieve specific filtration results (i.e. selective targeting of pollutants such as viruses and bacteria), and industrial scale apparatuses and methods. The filtrate material is composed of a nonwoven polymeric nanofiber mesh, and a porous substrate onto which the mesh is attached. The utilization of a nanofiltration platform also allows for ultra high efficacy at a fraction of volume of traditional filtration systems. With the product efficacy results there maybe enough value proposition to potential customers especially in contrast to the status quo product.

Institution.Name: University of California-Berkeley
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA, THE

Performance_Institution.Name: The Regents of the University of California

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit:

Our technology is a nanofiltration membrane able to transform organic waste into a cutting edge nanomembrane capable of targeted pollution removal in water and air mediums. During the I-Cops program, the team identified opportunities and markets for the commercialization and paved the way for further development.

By performing over 110 interviews with potential individual customers (B2C) as well as leading industry experts (B2B/B2C) and executives (B2C), ViaeX was able to confirm a strong market need for innovative filtration technologies. Our team identified various sub markets for the technology. Furthermore, we specified several distinct value propositions, each within the scope of our technology platform, for each market segment and derived suitable market entry strategies for each segment.

The most promising customer groups according to our research are:

-       Individual consumers (B2C)

-       Automotive

-       Clean room applications (e.g. hospitals)

-       Public and private water filtration institutions

Within each of these segments, we have acquired a distinct understanding of the importance of each product feature. This includes the environmental impact, various efficacy metrics, suitable cost structures, possible certifications, and production and form factor targets.

The next step for ViaeX is to bring the technology to market and to form a self-sustaining business around it. During I-Corps, we prepared for this by detailing key functions that create the most value and deriving a suitable company structure therefrom. This will help us to smoothen the transition into a proper company and to build an efficient and well-structured business from the very beginning.

Broader impact

The knowledge gained during the I-Corps grant period has allowed ViaeX to identify and engage potential early customers. The timely identification and acquisition of such early adopters is particularly important, as the success of the entire technology depends on it.

We have since been able to transfer our improved domain expertise into early traction. This will allow us to ensure and speed up the transition of the filtration market from traditional, inefficient, and environmentally harmful technologies to novel, specific, and responsible solutions, ultimately supporting humanity on its way to a sustainable future.

 


Last Modified: 05/03/2017
Modified by: Carol Mimura
